messages.text: Just popped out to pick up some food from Beantown Taqueria and had my laptop on me, so I’m sitting in my car outside beantown working on a PR. Feels like old cambridge.. Makes me want to pop into the miracle of science for a pint

messages.text: Someday soon this will be possible. I'm definitely going to start going to meetups after this... If there's one upside to months of quarantine, it's that the perpetual "eh, I'll go next time" excuse isn't going to cut it anymore

messages.text: Haha yeah

elements.text: Haha yeah

messages.text: I had just started to go to Meetups frequently the year and a half before COVID, it felt terrible to have that social / nerd outlet taken away from me.  There’s such a wide variety also in the Boston area, a great smorgasbord of nerdly delight!  (The QSP - Quantitative System Pharmacology ones were really cool)

messages.text: anyone willing to help a new Massachusetts person out with understanding the Boston area a little?

elements.text: anyone willing to help a new Massachusetts person out with understanding the Boston area a little?

messages.text: There's water on the East side. It's weird.

elements.text: There's water on the East side. It's weird.

messages.text: There is a river, on the one side there is Boston and on the other there is Cambridge

elements.text: There is a river, on the one side there is Boston and on the other there is Cambridge

messages.text: They are not the same City

elements.text: They are not the same City

messages.text: Okay so here's my situation. I live like in the middle of the state, but am interviewing at 2 places more in boston. One is northwest of the city, and the other is like literally on the coast inside boston. Are there any areas to avoid in general? Do most people commute in, or is it like DC where commuting is extremely painful?

elements.text: Okay so here's my situation. I live like in the middle of the state, but am interviewing at 2 places more in boston. One is northwest of the city, and the other is like literally on the coast inside boston. Are there any areas to avoid in general? Do most people commute in, or is it like DC where commuting is extremely painful?

messages.text: what I mean by extremely painful is... I once left 2 hrs early and was still unacceptably late to an interview in DC while being sure I was going to die at least 1x.

elements.text: what I mean by extremely painful is... I once left 2 hrs early and was still unacceptably late to an interview in DC while being sure I was going to die at least 1x.

messages.text: Just get a second apartment for the weekdays. You can probably get a studio for $8,000/month.

elements.text: Just get a second apartment for the weekdays. You can probably get a studio for $8,000/month.

messages.text: If you think of the Charles as being a straight line, you will be very confused about navigation

elements.text: If you think of the Charles as being a straight line, you will be very confused about navigation

messages.text: Took me a while to figure this out after moving from New York where the rivers are straight lines

elements.text: Took me a while to figure this out after moving from New York where the rivers are straight lines

messages.text: (roughly)

elements.text: (roughly)

messages.text: that happened to me when I moved from Cleveland to Pittsburgh with roads. Went from grid system to like bridges ontop of bridges connected to brick roads on inclines sharper then most people sled on. So I think I get it now, I asked the interviewer effectively "how do people live here?" and the one job is on the outskirts of cambridge and boston in a nice area, so it seems easy

messages.text: Cleveland. Pittsburgh. Boston. You following me man? I’ve lived all those places.

elements.text: Cleveland. Pittsburgh. Boston. You following me man? I’ve lived all those places.

messages.text: Family is from outside Cleveland and I went to CWRU for undergrad. I did grad school at Pitt and lived in the ’burgh for 5 years. I used to say that Boston was a bigger, more expensive Pittsburgh. But less bridges. And more oceans.

elements.text: Family is from outside Cleveland and I went to CWRU for undergrad. I did grad school at Pitt and lived in the ’burgh for 5 years. I used to say that Boston was a bigger, more expensive Pittsburgh. But less bridges. And more oceans.

messages.text: Oh I wish that was my story. I went from Cleveland -> Pgh -> Newark DE -> Charlottesville VA -> Ann Arbor MA -> now Westborough MA.

elements.text: Oh I wish that was my story. I went from Cleveland -> Pgh -> Newark DE -> Charlottesville VA -> Ann Arbor MA -> now Westborough MA.

messages.text: Ann Arbor, MI?

elements.text: Ann Arbor, MI?

messages.text: I mean, there were some other jaunts I left out. Houston, TX and Nashville, TN being the two main ones.
